member.name: P:NLog.Targets.DatabaseTarget.CommandText
member.summary: The text of the SQL command to be run on each log level.
member.remarks: Typically this is a SQL INSERT statement or a stored procedure call. It should use the database-specific parameters (marked as @parameter for SQL server or :parameter for Oracle, other data providers have their own notation) and not the layout renderers, because the latter is prone to SQL injection attacks. The layout renderers should be specified as <parameters />> instead.

member.name: P:NLog.Targets.DatabaseTarget.CommandTextLayout
member.summary: The text of the SQL command to be run on each log level.

It should use the database-specific parameters (marked as @parameter for SQL server or :parameter for Oracle, other data providers have their own notation) and not the layout renderers, because the latter is prone to SQL injection attacks. The layout renderers should be specified as <parameters />< instead.

member.name: T:NLog.Targets.FileTarget
member.summary: Writes logging messages to one or more files.

member.name: M:NLog.Targets.FileTarget.NeedsStackTrace
member.summary: Determines whether stack trace information should be gathered during log event processing. It calls on Layout and FileName parameters.
member.returns:
0 - don't include stack trace
1 - include stack trace without source file information
2 - include full stack trace

member.name: M:NLog.Targets.FileTarget.Append(NLog.LogEventInfo)
member.summary: Writes the specified logging event to a file specified in the FileName parameter.

member.name: P:NLog.Targets.FileTarget.FileName
member.summary: The name of the file to write to.
member.remarks: This FileName string is a layout which may include instances of layout renderers. This lets you use a single target to write to multiple files.
member.example: The following value makes NLog write logging events to files based on the log level in the directory where the application runs. ${basedir}/${level}.log All Debug messages will go to Debug.log, all Info messages will go to Info.log and so on. You can combine as many of the layout renderers as you want to produce an arbitrary log file name.

member.name: P:NLog.Targets.FileTarget.CreateDirs
member.summary: Create directories if they don't exist.

member.name: P:NLog.Targets.FileTarget.KeepFileOpen
member.summary: Keep log file open instead of opening and closing it on each logging event.
member.remarks: Setting this property to True helps improve performance but is not recommended in multithreaded or multiprocess scenarios because the file is kept locked and other processes cannot write to it which effectively prevents logging.

member.name: P:NLog.Targets.FileTarget.AutoFlush
member.summary: Automatically flush the file buffers after each log message.

member.name: P:NLog.Targets.FileTarget.BufferSize
member.summary: Log file buffer size in bytes.

member.name: P:NLog.Targets.FileTarget.Encoding
member.summary: File encoding.
member.remarks: Can be any encoding name supported by System.Text.Encoding.GetEncoding() e.g. windows-1252, iso-8859-2.

member.name: P:NLog.Targets.FileTarget.ConcurrentWrites
member.summary: Enables concurrent writes to the log file by multiple processes.
member.remarks: This prevents the log files from being kept open and makes NLog retry file writes until a write succeeds. This allows for logging in multiprocess environment.

member.name: P:NLog.Targets.FileTarget.ConcurrentWriteAttempts
member.summary: The number of times the write is appended on the file before NLog discards the log message.

member.name: P:NLog.Targets.FileTarget.ConcurrentWriteAttemptDelay
member.summary: The delay in milliseconds to wait before attempting to write to the file again.
member.remarks: The actual delay is a random value between 0 and the value specified in this parameter. On each failed attempt the delay base is doubled up to times.
member.example:
Assuming that ConcurrentWriteAttemptDelay is 10 the time to wait will be:
a random value between 0 and 10 milliseconds - 1st attempt
a random value between 0 and 20 milliseconds - 2nd attempt
a random value between 0 and 40 milliseconds - 3rd attempt
a random value between 0 and 80 milliseconds - 4th attempt
...
and so on.

member.summary: Loops through all loggers previously returned by and recalculates their target and filter list. Useful after modifying the configuration programmatically to ensure that all loggers have been properly configured.

member.name: M:NLog.LogManager.DisableLogging
member.summary: Decreases the log enable counter and if it reaches -1 the logs are disabled.
member.remarks: Logging is enabled if the number of calls is greater than or equal to calls.
member.returns: An object that iplements IDisposable whose Dispose() method reenables logging. To be used with C# using () statement.

member.name: M:NLog.LogManager.EnableLogging
member.summary: Increases the log enable counter and if it reaches 0 the logs are disabled.
member.remarks: Logging is enabled if the number of calls is greater than or equal to calls.

member.name: M:NLog.LogManager.IsLoggingEnabled
member.summary: Returns if logging is currently enabled.
member.returns: if logging is currently enabled, otherwise.
member.remarks: Logging is enabled if the number of calls is greater than or equal to calls.

member.name: T:NLog.NDC
member.summary: Nested Diagnostics Context - a thread-local structure that keeps a stack of strings and provides methods to output them in layouts Mostly for compatibility with log4net.

member.summary: Gets the top NDC message but doesn't remove it.
